c.c. @shaunak

Another interesting thing is that if I use following link https://instabase.com/saikat_biswa, it gives error response.

if endpoint name is some already existing instabase employee name or repo, it gives the response as shown in above screenshoot

@Saikat can you confirm that same behaviour exists with any user name?
yeah, but if you remove one character from my name, it gives error response.
Right, that was my finding too. That makes it easy for attackers to conclude whether an username is present or not.

I am not sure if this poses a security risk or not, since unauthorised folks can still not access the file system. It’s just that they can still figure out usernames by trying different urls using a script or something. I am guessing this won’t be having any rate limit.

Just thought about mentioning this here, in case there are potentially bigger risks due to the implementation here than what I imagined.

This does pose a security risk. 

This endpoint could allow a malicious hacker to enumerate users and brute force their passwords for all instances of instabase. This could lead to unauthorized disclosure of data in our customer instances if they are successful.

To mitigate the risk, we should enforce mfa on all user accounts so even if they could enumerate user lists and brute force passwords, they wouldn't be able to sign in successfully.

This is something, you could also ask in <#C03RM5VJ28G|> to consult with our security consultants

@karen, what’s more interesting for me now is the fact I got different responses for the url (https://instabase.com/admin) you shared (attached the screenshots - both are done in incognito and not logged in), haha.

Thanks for the reply though. I cross posted it in <#C03RM5VJ28G|>
FYI: This the reference thread (https://instabase.slack.com/archives/C03RM5VJ28G/p1683122121621649) over there.
This is part of the functionality that includes public subspaces; I assume that if public subspaces are not enabled with the site setting then this would be blocked?

Right, that could be it @Jessica. S*o maybe this is expected behaviour*, but in the original screenshot it showed “No subspaces to view” because I had no public space in my account, which aligns to what you are saying but still discloses the fact that “saikat_biswas” is an user to individuals on the public web. Maybe this is not a big deal at all, haha.

As for the above two screenshots where I faced two different responses when I was  accessing https://instabase.com/admin. After taking another look at them it seems it was a miss on my part for the one erroring out - I had used - https://instabase.com/admin/ (with a forward slash in the end), that seems to be the reason :sweat_smile:, @karen. So it’s expected, haha.

Hi Jessica,
How can one know whether the sub-space is public?
"Project" Sub-space is shown here, but I don't remember creating this as Public. Also attaching some screenshots of "Project" Sub-space

So on prod, we have permanently disabled public repos at the deployment level. This means that all repos (even if they were marked public before) are private, and you won’t see anything about public repos in the UI.
I don’t think we have made a change to block this endpoint entirely if public subspaces are disabled though, which is why we still see this view here. I’ll add a ticket to track this. fyi @Xindi Xu
